title: Docs on handling multiple PRs

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
This isn't quite accurate - it only updates the PR if you push a descendent of the PR head.
content.html: This isn't quite accurate - it only updates the PR if you push a descendent of the PR head.

content.raw: Can you use just "push" instead of "push back".  The latter isn't a commonly used hg term so it might be a bit confusing.
content.html: Can you use just "push" instead of "push back". The latter isn't a commonly used hg term so it might be a bit confusing.

content.raw: I think this is a better, more general workflow. Can you move it above the first suggestion? You might even want to suggest adding a command alias for this action to their .hgrc.
content.html: I think this is a better, more general workflow. Can you move it above the first suggestion? You might even want to suggest adding a command alias for this action to their .hgrc.

content.raw: It might be worth mentioning bookmarks.  One win is that you don't need to force-push if you push a bookmark that is attached to a new head.
content.html: It might be worth mentioning bookmarks. One win is that you don't need to force-push if you push a bookmark that is attached to a new head.

content.raw:
Updated to address your comments, @ngoldbaum, except for the bookmarks part.  From the email exchange before, this is what you had listed for bookmarks:

-----

```
#!bash

Bookmarks come in at the point where you create the new head.  Instead of just <do work>, I could have created a new bookmark:

hg bookmark mybookmark
<do work>
hg commit -m "I did some work"
push push -B mybookmark -f https://bitbucket.org/my_username/yt

The bookmark just names the commit head.  I tend not to use bookmarks for one-commit bugfixes but they're definitely useful for longer lived work.
```

-----

I think there is a typo in that the first 'push' should be 'hg'?  Also, it looks like you are still forcing the push.

Sorry, I'm not so familiar with the bookmarks workflow, so please correct me if I am missing something.
content.html:
Updated to address your comments, Nathan Goldbaum, except for the bookmarks part. From the email exchange before, this is what you had listed for bookmarks:

Bookmarks come in at the point where you create the new head.  Instead of just <do work>, I could have created a new bookmark:

hg bookmark mybookmark
<do work>
hg commit -m "I did some work"
push push -B mybookmark -f https://bitbucket.org/my_username/yt

The bookmark just names the commit head.  I tend not to use bookmarks for one-commit bugfixes but they're definitely useful for longer lived work.

I think there is a typo in that the first 'push' should be 'hg'? Also, it looks like you are still forcing the push.

Sorry, I'm not so familiar with the bookmarks workflow, so please correct me if I am missing something.

content.raw: The -f I included was a mistake, it's not needed.  Try it yourself.
content.html: The -f I included was a mistake, it's not needed. Try it yourself.

content.raw: There's no need to link to the alias extension, it's been in core mercurial since hg 1.3.
content.html: There's no need to link to the alias extension, it's been in core mercurial since hg 1.3.

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
All tests pass. Good job!
All tests pass. Good job!
Typo
Maybe add a note about ssh?

agreed, I like ssh -- the key is that you use hg@bitbucket.org.  E.g., I have:

myyt = ssh://hg@bitbucket.org/mzingale/yt-new
content.html:
agreed, I like ssh -- the key is that you use hg@bitbucket.org. E.g., I have:

myyt = ssh://hg@bitbucket.org/mzingale/yt-new

content.raw: Thanks for writing this up.

I actually use SSH myself, but thought I'd go with HTTPS since the rest of the doc does so.

In any case, I added a `.. note::` about SSH a little higher up in the doc, as I think it belongs there.  Let me know what you think.
content.html:
I actually use SSH myself, but thought I'd go with HTTPS since the rest of the doc does so.

In any case, I added a .. note:: about SSH a little higher up in the doc, as I think it belongs there. Let me know what you think.

content.raw: good by me.
All tests pass. Good job!
missing `:ref:` for *SSH key*
There doesn't need to be one: http://docutils.sourceforge.net/docs/user/rst/quickref.html#external-hyperlink-targets
ok, sorry for the noise. I thought it didn't render correctly, but I was looking at the wrong place

description:
Based on our [email discussion](http://lists.spacepope.org/pipermail/yt-dev-spacepope.org/2014-September/013686.html) about how to handle multiple PR's with BitBucket's auto-update "feature," I've added a section to the Developing docs.  I listed the method @ngoldbaum suggested, in addition to the workflow I've been using, based on the feedback that @MatthewTurk gave.  I didn't include Matt's description of using the remotebranches extension, because it is very similar to the flow I have been using.  

Also, one needs the Sphinx Bootstrap theme to build the docs - so I updated the docs to reflect that.
